title: Willingham Woods Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Paul Sumner / Forest Hide
images.caption: Forest Hide. You can just see the hide at the end of the track.

images.title: steven ruffles / Hamilton hill trig point.
images.caption: Hamilton hill trig point. On the edge of the woods.

images.title: Paul Sumner / Forest Path
images.caption: A forest ride just north Chapel Hill.

images.title: Michael Patterson / Dog Kennel Wood
images.caption: Dog Kennel Wood. This track through the woods leads to Dog Kennel Farm. It is also a byway through Willingham Woods. The woods are so named after the dog kennels for the now demolished Willingham Hall

images.title: Richard Croft / Willingham Woods
images.caption: Track to Dairy Farm and the Forestry Commission office through the woods.

images.title: Richard Croft / Turnpike milestone
images.caption: Turnpike milestone. Tealby milestone in the woods, showing 1 mile & 6 furlongs to Rasen and 13 miles 0 furlongs to Louth. Installed after the road was turnpiked in 1765

description: These woods near Market Rasen have miles of good footpaths and cycling trails to try. This route follows the Lindsey Trail which runs through the centre of the forest for about 1.5 miles. You can start from the car park just off the Willingham Road from Market Rasen. If you are bringing your bike to the woods please keep on the stone paths. Walkers can further explore the site on a number of alternative footpaths marked on the maps below. There's pretty ponds and wildlife including woodland birds and deer to look out for. The site also has a good kisok a with wide range of hot and cold snacks, drinks and ice cream. To continue your walking in the area head east towards the village of Tealby where you can pick up the Viking Way long distance trail. It will take you on a tour of the beautiful Lincolnshire Wolds .
